name: 1,3-Dinitronaphthalene
Reason: To predict the melting point of 1,3-dinitronaphthalene, we must consider the influences of its structural features. The base unit naphthalene has a melting point of 80.5°C. Adding two nitro groups to the naphthalene ring system will raise the melting point due to increased molecular weight and the formation of strong intermolecular interactions such as dipole-dipole attractions. Each nitro group is associated with an increase in melting point due to these effects. The symmetric placement of the nitro groups in the 1,3 positions also supports a more orderly lattice structure, enhancing the melting point further. Quantitatively, each nitro group can be estimated to contribute approximately 40°C to the melting point, based on the known influence of nitro groups on aromatic compounds.

name: 1,3-Dinitronaphthalene
Reason: To accurately predict the melting point of 1,3-dinitronaphthalene, the impact of the nitro groups must be quantitatively assessed. Starting with the parent compound naphthalene, which has a melting point of 80.5°C, each added nitro group increases molecular weight and provides strong intermolecular attractions such as dipole-dipole forces and possible hydrogen bonding with traces of moisture, both of which contribute to elevating the melting point. However, an estimate of 40°C increase per nitro group seems overestimated since aromatic nitro compounds typically show a lower increment due to the size and electron-withdrawing nature of the nitro group. A more conservative estimate of the nitro group's influence on the melting point would be around 20°C to 30°C. Given the symmetric substitution, let's choose the higher end of this estimate at 30°C per nitro group.
